admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The project identifies two distinct
            parts: a) the rural basic health services and production of
            non-vaccine pharmaceuticals, with an overall satisfactory
            outcome; and, b) the vaccine production, whose outcome
            remained deficient. Even though some deficiencies in
            recurrent costs were identified in the rural health
            development component, success was achieved in upgrading the
            quality of preventive, maternal/child health, and basic
            health services. In addition, the drug component improved
            the pharmaceutical quality and safety of products, while
            research strengthened the capacity for health policy
            formulation, as well as health insurance evaluation schemes.
            Conversely, the delays and cost overruns in the vaccine
            production, caused mixed results, though full production
            will start by the year 2000, with a substantial transfer of
            biotechnology. The key lessons learned suggest attention to
            recurrent costs in the design and implementation of low-cost
            rural health projects, with monitoring and evaluation
            frameworks integrated in the formulation phase; testing and
            verification during implementation could be achieved through
            the development of a research agenda. The complexity in
            vaccine production requires technical expertise and
            industrial know-how, therefore this challenge would be
            better achieved within industrial projects, in accordance
            with financial and economic methods.
